bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, April 4, 1923

div1.p: Hanson must decide whether to stay in private practice or resume yellow fever work with the International Health Board. Enclosing a telegram from Russell, he asks Carter if there is suspicion of yellow fever in Colombia.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, April 4, 1923
div1.opener:
HENRY HANSON, M. D.
LABORATORY
460 ST. JAMES BLDG.
JACKSONVILLE, FLORIDA
April, 4, 1923,
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am enclosing a copy of telegram received from
Col. Russel, which will be self explanatory. This has rather upset all my
plans and I am as much up in the air about what I am to do and about a
home for the family as I was while in Baltimore. I replied stating that I
would consider it if they would assure me permanent work, and a good salary.
I did not state the amount, and dont know whether or not I ought to do so.
They know what I was getting in Peru, but I know that they also think that
is more than they can pay, or rather it is more than they have planned to pay.

The situation with me is, as you know, that I have gone to considerable
expense in getting down here, getting my things to gather once more, the cost
of setting up house keeping again, besides the expense which I have gone to
on my preliminary laboratory equipment. This would all be practically a com-
plete loss if I should go on this work. The work here is looking promising
even at this early stage before I have made any announcement to the profession
as a whole. What I have done so far has been simply local work for Jacksonville
Surgeons and Physicians, and I have had as much as I could do up to date. It
would be possible for me to do more if I were better equipped for it, but as
it is I am employing an office helper now (not a highly skilled one, but one
who does take care of a part of the routine) and we can not do very much more
than the work which we are getting, unless we improve the equipment consider-
ably. This of course I can not do until it is decided what I am to do for the
I.H.B., and what they think they have in mind for me to do.

It seems to me that if I am to tear up and go out on another foreign
detail that they will have to plan on continuous employment, since one can
not go on a detail of this kind for a sh rt period and then be turned loose
to start all over again. Even I am getting too old for that, and I have not
got the pep I had before the work in Peru.

Last fall Dr. White offered $8000, per annum and expenses (travel expense)
in a lump sum that looks like a pretty good salary, and I realize that in this
country it would be a very good salary, but when one is out on these foreign
details it is not so much as it looks, especially if it is only for a year or
two. At present it has taken all my savings to get established again, and if
I tear up now most of that will be lost, especially what I have spent on the
laboratory. Still I am very much interested in the work and am willing to
make a reasonable sacrifice to help out in this big yellow fever program.

The family will be the greatest sufferer in this thing. It is a
question where one could satisfactorily locate them. Where to establish the
home which must be established? If one were to work with them permanently
it might be best to set up housekeeping in some place near New York, such
as Long Island, near Headquarters.

I wired Russel that I would consider it and later wrote him but I
can not very well make any final decision until he gives me some more definite
program to consider. Simply to go on this survey of Columbia, could not be
considered except for a salary of $1000, permonth and all incidental travel
expense. I stated that I could start about May first if things could be satis-
factorily arranged.
What is in the wind-is there some suspicion of yellow fever in Columbia?

Well here I am bothering you again, but I know of not better place to go
for advice.
With the best regards from all the Hansons,
